choices.text: Most of them are malignant
C-peptide level is elevated
It is not associated with MEN 1 syndrome

questions.solution:
Ans. C) C-peptide level is elevated

 

Option C:

 

This is correct. Insulinomas cause increased production of insulin, and because C-peptide is co-released with insulin, its levels are also elevated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Alpha cell tumor: This is incorrect; insulinomas arise from beta cells of the pancreas, which are responsible for the production of insulin.

 

Option B: Most of them are malignant: The majority of insulinomas are benign; only a small percentage are malignant.

 

Option D: It is not associated with MEN 1 syndrome: This is incorrect; insulinomas can be associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulinomas are beta-cell tumors, most of which are benign and can present with hypoglycemia and elevated levels of insulin and C-peptide in the blood. They may also be associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1124

questions.text: An elderly female with mediastinal mass undergoes a microscopic examination showing red cell aplasia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thymoma

Option B:

Direct lines from Ref: Robbins. “In addition to myasthenia gravis, thymomas may be associated with several other paraneoplastic syndromes. These include in rough order of frequency, pure red cell aplasia, hypogammaglobulinemia, and multi organ autoimmunity”.

Thymomas are tumors originating from the epithelial cells of the thymus and can be associated with various paraneoplastic syndromes, including pure red cell aplasia. This is a condition where there is a selective decrease in red blood cell precursors in the bone marrow, leading to anemia.

Explanation:

Option A. Bronchogenic carcinoma: Bronchogenic carcinoma refers to a type of lung cancer originating from the bronchi. Although it can present with a mediastinal mass, it is not typically associated with pure red cell aplasia, which is a reduction in the production of red blood cells.

Option C. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is a diverse group of blood malignancies that includes any kind of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas. Types of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma can involve the mediastinum but are not typically associated with pure red cell aplasia.

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma:  Squamous cell carcinoma can arise in various organs, including the lungs, but is not commonly associated with pure red cell aplasia or mediastinal masses unless it is metastatic from another primary location.

Educational Objective:

Thymomas are mediastinal tumors that may be associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, including pure red cell aplasia, which is characterized by a selective decrease in red blood cell precursors.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/e p493

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes imaging for suspected pituitary adenoma. The radiological report indicates a pituitary mass. The pituitary adenomas are regarded as macroadenomas when their size is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) > 1 cm

 

Option A:

 

Pituitary adenomas are designated as the following:

 

  • Microadenomas (if less than 1 cm in diameter);
  • Macroadenomas (if they exceed 1 cm in diameter).

 

Educational objective:

 

The pituitary adenomas are regarded as macroadenomas when their size is > 1cm.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1293

choices.text: Diabetes insipidus
Lyme disease
Diabetes mellitus

questions.text: Necrobiosis lipoidica is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diabetes mellitus

 

Option C:

 

 

Lesions of necrobiosis lipoidica are found primarily on the shins (90%), and patients can have diabetes mellitus or develop it subsequently. Characteristic findings include a central yellow color, atrophy (transparency), telangiectasias, and a red to red-brown border. Ulcerations can also develop within the plaques. Biopsy specimens show necrobiosis of collagen and granulomatous inflammation.

 

Necrobiosis lipoidica is a chronic skin condition that is often associated with diabetes mellitus. It is characterized by well-defined, waxy, yellowish-brown plaques typically located on the shins, with potential for ulceration.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Diabetes insipidus: This is a condition characterized by polyuria and polydipsia due to issues with vasopressin (ADH); it is not associated with skin changes like necrobiosis lipoidica.

 

Option B: Lyme disease: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi and transmitted by ticks, Lyme disease can present with a variety of symptoms including erythema migrans, but not necrobiosis lipoidica.

 

Option D: Simmonds disease: Also known as Sheehan's syndrome, is postpartum hypopituitarism, not associated with necrobiosis lipoidica.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Necrobiosis lipoidica is a skin condition primarily associated with diabetes mellitus, presenting as well-circumscribed, waxy plaques typically on the shins with a yellowish center and telangiectatic borders.

questions.text: Mauriac’s syndrome is characterized by all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cardiomegaly

 

Mauriac syndrome is a rare complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus in children associated with hepatomegaly, growth impairment and cushingoid features.

 

This is not a feature of Mauriac's syndrome. The syndrome is instead associated with hepatomegaly due to the glycogen storage in the liver.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Diabetes: Mauriac's syndrome is specifically associated with poorly controlled type 1 diabetes mellitus in children.

 

Option B: Obesity: Despite being a sign of poor glycemic control, obesity is not a characteristic of Mauriac's syndrome. Instead, patients may present with Cushingoid features.

 

Option C: Dwarfism: Growth impairment or stunted growth is a classical component of Mauriac's syndrome due to chronic hyperglycemia and its metabolic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mauriac's syndrome is associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus in children and presents with hepatomegaly, growth retardation, and Cushingoid features, but not with cardiomegaly.

questions.text: What is the primary contributor to insulin resistance in liver disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Steatosis

 

Option B:

 

The accumulation of fat in the liver, or hepatic steatosis, is closely associated with insulin resistance. It impairs the liver's response to insulin, particularly affecting the inhibition of gluconeogenesis and increasing insulin resistance in peripheral tissues.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Decreased insulin release: This refers to a problem with insulin secretion from the pancreas, not resistance at the level of hepatic or peripheral tissues and does not directly relate to liver disease.

 

Option C: Hepatocyte dysfunction: While hepatocyte dysfunction can contribute to metabolic disturbances, it is a broader term that includes various liver impairments, not specific to insulin resistance.

 

Option D: Decreased ‘C’ peptide level: C-peptide is a byproduct of insulin production. Lower levels may indicate reduced insulin secretion but are not a direct cause of insulin resistance in the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatic steatosis, or fatty liver disease, is a significant contributor to insulin resistance, which impairs both the liver's response to insulin and the peripheral action of insulin.

 

Ref: Robbin 10th/ 1140, Joslin’s Diabetes Mellitus 14/e p436

questions.text: According to ADA guidelines, the diagnosis of diabetes is made when the fasting blood glucose is more than?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 126 mg/dL

 

Option A:

 

The ADA sets the threshold for the diagnosis of diabetes at fasting blood glucose level of 126 mg/dL or higher on two separate occasions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: 100 mg/dL: This is considered the upper limit of normal for fasting glucose, with levels between 100 mg/dL and 125 mg/dL indicating impaired fasting glucose or prediabetes.

 

Option C: 140 mg/dL: This level is above the diagnostic criteria for diabetes when measured fasting and may also indicate diabetes if it is a 2-hour postprandial or oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) value.

 

Option D: 200 mg/dL: A level of 200 mg/dL or higher may indicate diabetes if it is from a random plasma glucose test accompanied by classic symptoms of hyperglycemia or hyperglycemic crisis, or during an OGTT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fasting blood glucose level of 126 mg/dL or higher is diagnostic for diabetes mellitus according to ADA guidelines.

 

ADA diagnostic criteria for diabetes (need any one of the following):

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /1110

questions.text: Most common association in MEN I is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastrinoma

 

Option A:

 

Gastrinomas, which secrete gastrin, are among the most common functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with MEN I and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Insulinoma: Insulinomas are also associated with MEN I and result in hypoglycemia due to unregulated insulin secretion, but they are less common compared to gastrinomas.

 

Option C: Lipoma: While patients with MEN I may develop non-endocrine tumors like lipomas, these are not as commonly associated with the syndrome as endocrine tumors.

 

Option D: Glucagonoma: Glucagonomas, which secrete glucagon, are rare pancreatic endocrine tumors and are less commonly associated with MEN I than gastrinomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of MEN I, gastrinomas are the most commonly associated functional pancreatic endocrine tumors, often leading to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by peptic ulcer disease, gastroesophageal reflux, and diarrhea due to hypergastrinemia.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1140

questions.text: What marker is indicative of a non-functional pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chromogranin-A

 

Option A:

 

Chromogranin A is a protein found in the secretory vesicles of neuroendocrine cells. It is a commonly used marker for PNETs, especially when they do not secrete hormones or their secretion is not clinically apparent.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: CD100: CD100 is not a recognized marker for PNETs. CD markers are generally used in the characterization of lymphocytes and other cells of the immune system.

 

Option C: CEA: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker associated with colorectal cancer and some other adenocarcinomas, not specifically with PNETs.

 

Option D: PSA: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is used as a marker for prostate cancer. It has no relevance in the diagnosis of PNETs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromogranin A is a marker for pancreatic non-functional neuroendocrine tumours.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 720

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of bilateral lower extremity swelling and fatigue for the past several months. He has a past medical history significant for poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and obesity. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum creatinine and proteinuria. A renal biopsy is performed, which demonstrates deposition of amyloid proteins in the glomeruli. Which of the following types of diabetes mellitus is most commonly associated with this renal complication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type II DM

 

Option C:

 

Type II DM is associated with the deposition of amyloid in the pancreatic islets, contributing to β-cell dysfunction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Maturity onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is characterized by monogenic defects of β-cell function but is not typically associated with amyloid deposition in the islets.

 

Option B: Type I DM is an autoimmune disorder leading to β-cell destruction and does not typically involve amyloid deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amyloid deposition in the islets of Langerhans is a feature specifically associated with Type II diabetes mellitus, which can contribute to the dysfunction of insulin-secreting pancreatic β-cells.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 261

choices.text: Anemia of chronic disease

questions.text: A 51-year-old man Sonu with a history of recurrent calcium-containing renal stones presents to the emergency room with excruciating flank pain and blood in the urine. This patient is likely to have which of the following underlying disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperparathyroidism

 

Option C:

 

The patient’s history of recurrent urolithiasis with calcium containing stones implies a disorder in the regulation of calcium concentration. Hyperparathyroidism is associated with increased PTH levels, which can produce hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria, and, ultimately, renal stones.

 

Primary hyperparathyroidism leads to elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, resulting in increased bone resorption, hypercalcemia, and hypercalciuria, which can cause calcium-containing renal stones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Anemia of chronic disease – This condition is associated with long-standing, chronic illnesses that lead to alterations in iron metabolism and erythropoiesis but is not directly related to calcium stone formation.

 

Option B: Chronic Proteus infection – While Proteus bacteria can increase the risk for struvite stone formation due to urease production, it is not typically associated with calcium stone formation.

 

Option D: Hyperaldosteronism – This condition leads to hypertension and hypokalemia due to excess aldosterone and is not typically associated with calcium-containing renal stone disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recurrent calcium-containing renal stones may suggest an underlying disorder of calcium metabolism, such as hyperparathyroidism, due to its association with increased PTH levels, hypercalcemia, and hypercalciuria.

 

Ref: Robbins 9/e p1103

questions.text: The laboratory screening test which suggests normal thyroid function is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TSH

 

Option A:

 

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is the most sensitive screening test for thyroid function because it can detect even minor deviations in thyroid hormone levels due to its inverse relationship with free thyroid hormone levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Free T4: Free T4 measurement reflects the biologically active portion of thyroxine and can be normal in early or mild forms of thyroid dysfunction.

 

Option C: T3: Total T3 levels can be affected by factors that influence binding proteins and are not the first line of screening; they are more helpful in diagnosing hyperthyroidism or in certain clinical situations like T3 toxicosis.

 

Option D: Free T3: Similar to T3, Free T3 is not the first line of screening but rather used for specific clinical indications and is less commonly measured than TSH or Free T4.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TSH is the most sensitive initial screening test for evaluating thyroid function because it reflects the pituitary's response to the serum concentration of free thyroid hormones, particularly free T4.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1083

questions.text: Which is not seen in MEN I:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Medullary carcinoma thyroid

 

Option D:

 

MEN-1, or Wermer syndrome, is characterized by abnormalities involving the parathyroid, pancreas, and pituitary glands; thus the mnemonic device, the 3Ps

 

Parathyroid: Primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common manifestation of MEN-1

 

Pancreas: Endocrine tumors of the pancreas like gastrinomas associated with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome and insulinomas

 

Pituitary: The most frequent anterior pituitary tumor encountered in MEN-1 is a prolactinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type I (MEN I) is characterized by the presence of tumors in parathyroid glands, anterior pituitary, and pancreatic islets, and does not commonly include medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, which is associated with MEN II.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1091

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with symptoms of hypercalcemia, peptic ulcer disease, and a pituitary mass on imaging. Given these clinical features, which of the following conditions is least likely to be part of the patient's underlying syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior pituitary tumors

 

Option B:

 

  • MEN-1, or Wermer syndrome is characterized by anterior pituitary tumours and not posterior pituitary tumours.
  • MEN-1 syndrome is caused by germline mutations in the MEN1 tumor suppressor gene, which encodes a protein called menin.

 

MEN-1 syndrome involves tumors of the anterior pituitary gland, not the posterior pituitary. Symptoms are typically caused by excess hormone production, like prolactin or growth hormone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Foregut carcinoid - Foregut carcinoids (including those found in the thymus, lung, and stomach) are part of the spectrum of MEN-1 syndrome, although less common compared to other manifestations.

 

Option C: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors - These tumors are a hallmark of MEN-1 and can produce a variety of symptoms depending on the hormone they secrete (e.g., gastrin, insulin).

 

Option D: Parathyroid hyperplasia - Primary hyperparathyroidism due to parathyroid hyperplasia is the most common feature of MEN-1 syndrome, causing hypercalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEN-1 syndrome, also known as Wermer syndrome, is characterized by anterior pituitary tumors, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, and parathyroid hyperplasia, but not by tumors of the posterior pituitary.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1129

questions.text: All of the following are feature of granulomatous thyroiditis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Painless

 

Option C:

 

Painless Granulomatous thyroiditis, also known as subacute thyroiditis or De Quervain's thyroiditis, is typically a painful condition. It presents with a tender, swollen thyroid gland and is often preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection. Pain in the neck, jaw, or ear is a common feature, and tenderness is elicited on palpation of the gland.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A:  In the initial phase of granulomatous (subacute) thyroiditis, there may be a transient hyperthyroid phase due to the inflammatory destruction of thyroid follicles leading to the release of preformed thyroid hormones into circulation.

 

Option B:  Following the hyperthyroid phase of granulomatous thyroiditis, there is a hypothyroid phase as the damaged thyroid may be temporarily unable to produce sufficient hormones. This is usually self-limited, and normal thyroid function often returns, but some patients may develop permanent hypothyroidism.

 

Option D:  Granulomatous thyroiditis is characterized histologically by granuloma formation with giant cells. These multinucleated giant cells are part of the body's response to inflammation and are involved in the degradation of thyroglobulin, which is released during the follicular destruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulomatous thyroiditis is the most common cause of thyroid pain, not a painless condition.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1093

questions.text: Brown tumour is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans C) Hyperparathyroidism

 

Option C:

 

Hyperparathyroidism is an excess of parathyroid hormone (PTH) in the body, which leads to increased calcium levels in the blood and bones. PTH stimulates the release of calcium from the bone, and in chronic cases, this can lead to osteitis fibrosa cystica, a condition where brown tumors may form. These lesions are osteolytic bone lesions caused by increased osteoclastic activity and fibrous tissue deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown tumors are associated with hyperparathyroidism and represent a severe manifestation of osteitis fibrosa cystica, where excessive bone resorption leads to fibrous and cystic bone changes.

choices.text: Pituitary tumor
Adrenal adenoma

questions.text: Most common cause of Cushing’s syndrome is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Exogenous corticosteroids

 

Option A:

 

The most frequent cause of Cushing's syndrome is the iatrogenic administration of exogenous corticosteroids. This can occur with prolonged use of oral, intravenous, or inhaled glucocorticoids for the treatment of various conditions such as asthma, autoimmune diseases, or after organ transplantation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: A pituitary adenoma that secretes adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) can cause Cushing's disease, which is a subset of Cushing's syndrome. This is the most common cause of endogenous Cushing's syndrome, but overall less common than the exogenous form caused by taking corticosteroid medications.

 

Option C: An adrenal adenoma is a benign tumor of the adrenal gland that can autonomously secrete cortisol. It's a less common cause of Cushing's syndrome compared to exogenous steroid use and pituitary tumors but should be considered, especially when ACTH levels are low.

 

Option D: Adrenal carcinomas are rare but can also cause Cushing's syndrome by secreting excessive amounts of cortisol. They are more aggressive than adenomas and can be associated with a worse prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exogenous corticosteroids are the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome, primarily due to the widespread use of corticosteroid medications for a variety of medical conditions.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1115

questions.text: Submucosal neuroma is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MEN II B

 

Option C:

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type II B (MEN II B) is associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuromas (which can be submucosal), marfanoid habitus, and intestinal ganglioneuromas. Submucosal neuromas are a characteristic finding in MEN II B and can be seen in the gastrointestinal tract, often leading to symptoms like constipation or diarrhea.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type I (MEN I) is a syndrome characterized by the presence of tumors in the parathyroid glands, pancreatic islet cells, and the anterior pituitary gland. Submucosal neuromas are not typically associated with MEN I.

 

Option B: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type II A (MEN II A) is a syndrome that includes medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism. It does not typically present with submucosal neuromas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Submucosal neuromas are associated with MEN II B and can contribute to the diagnosis of this syndrome.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1130

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Sipple Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperthyroidism

 

Option C:

 

  • Hyperthyroidism is not a feature of MEN 2A.

  • Sipple syndrome = MEN type 2A (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2A)

  • It is characterized by the classic triad:
    • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)
    • Pheochromocytoma
    • Parathyroid hyperplasia or adenoma leading to hyperparathyroidism 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Pheochromocytoma is a characteristic feature of MEN 2A and presents as a catecholamine-secreting tumor typically originating in the adrenal medulla.

 

Option B: Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a neuroendocrine tumor of the thyroid and a principal feature of MEN 2A. It arises from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid gland and secretes calcitonin.

 

Option D: Primary hyperparathyroidism is part of the MEN 2A syndrome and is due to hyperplasia or adenoma of the parathyroid glands leading to excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH).

 

Educational Objective:

 

While pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid carcinoma, and hyperparathyroidism are part of the Sipple syndrome, hyperthyroidism is not.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1130
